history.content:
It's difficult to give specific advice without knowing your past experience or specific interests, so I'll share some pretty general thoughts. I’ll also make some basic assumptions: you’re a CS/EECS major/minor, you don’t have experience in research, you’re not necessarily into the fundamental theory side of ML, you’re ok with or enjoy math. Also, I’ll just talk about deep learning (DL) because I think that’s most likely the thing that you’re interested in. But to be clear, AI and ML are much broader than DL. Even though DL has all the hype behind it, there are lots of important AI/ML research problems outside of DL.

For courses to take, I think Sahai’s general advice of EECS 126, EECS 127, and EECS 189 is good advice.

For resources outside of courses, there are so many great intro tutorials online that I don’t think I need to go into specifics about ways to get started in DL. But one piece of general advice is that one of the best ways to learn is to find DL models and implement them yourself. For example, you might want to start by implementing a basic neural net in Numpy (without using libraries like PyTorch or TensorFlow, which abstract everything away). Afterwards, you can start implementing more complicated neural nets by using research-standard libraries like PyTorch or TensorFlow.

For getting into DL research, you’re lucky to be at Berkeley! There are lots of great labs both inside and outside of the EECS department working on really interesting DL problems. There are a few ways of actually getting into a lab. A couple that I can think of are applying through URAP or contacting a professor, postdoc, or graduate student in the lab. Getting a response from a postdoc or graduate student tends to be more likely than getting a response from a professor. Even if you feel slightly under qualified, apply/ask anyways! You never know.

It’s difficult to answer what it’s like to work in DL research because it really varies quite a bit by the subfield of DL and the lab that you’re in. But I think that some things that people broadly share are that 1) it’s such a fast-moving field that exciting papers/ideas come out frequently, 2) it’s such a fast-moving field that it feels like we’re missing a lot of the basic building blocks of knowledge that can explain phenomena that we observe (see Rahimi and Recht’s “test of time” talk at NIPS), and 3) we spend a lot of time waiting for models to train.

TL;DR: learn to implement neural nets on your own, and there are lots of great labs at Berkeley that you can try to get into by contacting profs/postdocs/grad students
